Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Capsule Pipeline for Reservoir De-silting and for Mining
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impacts of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to support reservoir de-silting. The nation has a number of dams and reservoirs to produce low cost-electricity. However, sediments transported every year by floods consume the storage capacity of dams and must be removed. For example, the Hoover Dam is full to a depth of only 90 ft. Similarly, some 1430 dams are at risk of collapsing or overflowing from floods, such as the Prado Dam and Mojave Dam in California, and two dams collapsed in Michigan in 2020, flooding towns and displacing thousands of residents. Traditional dredging costs $20-70 per cubic yard and poses a major barrier to restoring the storage capacities of those dams. This project will reduce the cost to $8 per cubic yard by switching from a slurry to a capsule technology. The payback would be in the 1% power capacity restored from lower sediment accumulation. This could also protect turbines from erosion. <br/><br/>This SBIR Phase I project advances translation of a system to address sediment accumulation. The proposed project represents an extension of technologies to move pressed coal logs. The sediments are first pumped to shore from a depth of 50-200 ft. They are dewatered in settling ponds and excess water is returned to the reservoir. The dewatered sediments are then packed into large plastic capsules and sent to a dedicated pipeline some 30 miles away from the dam. Since the capsule is streamlined, it needs little water to be supported in the pipeline by hydrodynamic forces. For this purpose, a new natural gas fired capsule pump is developed; this liquid piston pump engine can pump up to 60 million gallons per day; it is also compact and does not need a complex system of locks and pump bypasses. It can be easily relocated to a new site and operates on low-cost natural gas. This transition from slurry to capsule pipeline technology represents a cost-effective method.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research of the market identified a number of reservoirs across the nation suffer from continuous accumulation of sediments and would require long distance transport of sediments. For example,

Tuttle Creek reservoir - Missouri River

  •  The reservoir used to have 30 miles of open water but is down to 14 miles now. It is considered to be #1 in need of repair amongst 400 dams in danger across the nation

Lewis and Clark Reservoir - Missouri River

  • It has large influx of sediments > 4 million cubic yards/year . The reservoir has lost 6 to 7 miles of open water river to sedimentation or 30% of its water storage capacity
  • The Delta is at 14 miles from dam and sediments would need to be moved downstream the dam as there is no space to store sediments.

 Imperial Reservoir (Nevada/California)

  • The reservoir is typically dredged once every 10 years to remove 2 million cubic yards
  • This is a diversion reservoir with no storage capacity  Pipes for pumping slurry are worn out from sand abrasion and will cost $20 million to replace. Managers would prefer a permanent installation that removes the incoming flux of sediments.

Lake Powell. Colorado River and San Juan Rivers.

 It has lost 7% of its storage capacity since it was built in 1963, with an average loss of 11 billion gallons per year, due to sedimentation, and a dwindling supply of water.

There are also a number of community owned reservoirs leased to power utilities. For example, in California there are some 80 reservoirs leased principally to the Pacific Gas & Electric Company. Many of the leases were signed some 50 years ago, and up for renewal. Many of the reservoirs have silted up, and communities would prefer restoration, de-silting and sometimes even total removal of dams. These smaller dams and reservoirs would benefit from our technology.

During the month of November 2021, the Pacific Northwest suffered from major floods particularly the Nooksack River and Skagit River. We received letters of support from the three privately owned hydropower dams on the Nooksack River, Smith Creek Hydro, Cascade Clean Energy LLC and  Westford Energy, LLC. Smith Creek Hydro produces 150 kW and its director has supported us with numerous discussions and may become our corporate partner during Phase II to install a commercial capsule pump launcher and hydraulic capsule pipeline during Phase II.

The hydraulic capsule pipeline presents a new solution to transport sediments removed by dredging from a water reservoir from the pool upstream a dam. Our proposed technology is particularly suitable to transport the dredged sediments over a distance of 10 to 20 km,

Past efforts to develop hydraulic coal log pipelines used very complex feeding systems with submerged conveyors, locks, feed and recirculating pumps that would not be suitable for dredging operation.

Our new invention operates on a much simpler approach more like a combination of a rotary feeder and a very high-speed jet pump that creates a vacuum in a chamber where the capsule is fed before leaving into the pipeline. This prevents water to rise to the computer. A patent application was filed.

We built a prototype of the capsule launcher and an 80 mm (3") diameter pipe loop x 30 m (100 ft). During tests capsules were launched successfully and continuously.

 This technology would eliminate abrasion of pipes and pumps from gravel or coarse sand usually removed by dredging.

The mathematical model developed, for operation of the pipeline confirmed that there is a range of velocity when substantial water and power can be saved over conventional slurry pipelines associated with transport of dredged sediments.

We also approached some ports with our technology. For example, the port of Houston and Galveston are moving towards pumping sediments at a distance of 30 km or 20 miles. There are very few sites near the port to place dredged sediments and the tendency has been to pump them far to the deep ocean and let the currents redistribute them.

We also approached the mining sector with our technology. We entered into an agreement with a mining company in Peru to start a study with their innovation group for the transport filtered tailings in a capsule pipeline,

A presentation was also made to a major mining company in Chile. We were referred to their innovation group to study the transport of ore in a capsule pipeline, as an alternative to conveyors particularly in some of the steep terrains encountered in the Andes mountains.

During phase II, we intend to focus on de-silting the reservoirs of the nation. There is a favorable climate as Congress passed the 21st Century Dam Safety Act in November 2021. Funds allocated by the Act has the potential to create numerous jobs in de-silting the reservoirs and our technology can play an important role.

 


Last Modified: 04/24/2022
Modified by: Baha Abulnaga
